when_to_use: When end-to-end host connectivity in a Clos/EBGP fabric is failing and you need to quickly determine whether the issue is underlay/BGP vs. host access (L2/L3) adjacency.
content: Start with simple, directional pings between hosts and to each host’s default gateway. Compare results both ways (A→B and B→A) and especially host→gateway. If a host cannot ping its own gateway while another host in the same pod can, localize the fault to the host-access segment (host NIC, L2 adjacency, gateway interface) rather than the spine/super-spine or BGP. This quickly narrows the fault domain before spending time on fabric-wide routing checks.
author: azure/gpt-5.2

when_to_use: When troubleshooting FRR/EBGP fabrics and CLI checks like `vtysh` fail or return `command not found`.
content: Don’t assume FRR is available via `vtysh`. First verify the control-plane presence using OS-level checks (e.g., `which vtysh`, `ps -ef | grep frr`, `systemctl status frr` with explicit error capture). If FRR tooling is missing, pivot to kernel evidence (routes, neighbors, interface state) to support the diagnosis instead of repeatedly issuing `vtysh` commands.
author: azure/gpt-5.2
